Indian clubs can help your HEMA skills, as long as you do not just replicate sword attacks with clubs...

In this video, Thierry shows the 2 ways to perform wrist circles, depending on the weight of the club and goals. Are you just swinging clubs for general health and conditioning, or do you practice HEMA? Let us know in the comments!

Visit our website to learn how to swing Indian clubs step by step.

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

❂ READY TO LEARN MORE?

All our educational material has been tested and structured since 2010, in a way that is easy for anyone to learn from home.

Best regards from Thierry & Ron

full grip without you know the white knuckle death grip on the on the club otherwise you're gonna tense up the whole arm and you can't really move that club okay so the ring grip is a fine way to get started to learn the movement and you know you can make those circles in both directions of course but then you want to sort of like graduate to being able to do them with a full grip so with the large heavy clubs most of the moves are based on attacks and by attacks i mean by moves where you cross the midline because that's our strongest uh movement pattern yeah so going away from the midline would be like akin to throwing a dart whereas you know crossing the midline you know you're sword fighting okay boom throwing a spare uh throwing an axe wrestling arm wrestling you know the winner is the guy that crosses the midline this is where we're strong and you lose by going away from the midline so the light clubs open different type of patterns you can do them you know very fancy linking all this kind of stuff but we went from you know the purpose of the indian club that was to train fighters and wrestlers to more of a spectator sport visual performance and this is where the clubs got lighter so you can do new patterns by changing grips you know doing the snakes and all this kind of stuff and it's very available for dexterity and stuff you know but if you're training for a hammer the full grip is the way to go doing the wrist circles with the full grip require more awareness mobility and coordination than using the ring grip okay so you have to practice and when you practice you don't want a stupidly heavy club okay now this club here is our palavendor gamma it's got a 40mm handle so it's still a very thick handle you can see like i'm just closing it here and this is what the forward wrist circle looks like now when we say wrist circle it's actually the club doing a circle because our wrist if you observe now is doing a type of rolling motion okay and the same when i go in reverse so when you practice you know you gotta figure out you gotta imagine you got a wall next to you so the club stays as perpendicular to the ground as possible while your elbow comes in transition position and then you've got the saber grip where the handle of the club is in the proponention of your forearm and kind of like all those moves around there using the saber grip okay so for hema they're the two main groups you need to master worry about and just have a firm grip but relaxed enough to be able to transition between those movements okay also important that you will
